title: Before 1 July 2020, will Nepal release its 2020 census results for Indian rhinoceros?
possible_answers: Yes, counting less than 550 Indian rhinoceros
Yes, counting between 550 and 600 Indian rhinoceros
Yes, counting more than 600 but less than 650 Indian rhinoceros
Yes, counting 650 or more Indian rhinoceros

I'm still banking on the idea deaths are related to the carrying capacity of the land and no other reason, though the loss of feed grass does impact carrying capacity negatively. I'm also hedging with a 2% No, because the question relies not only on the census but the government's ability to release it before 1 July 2020.

I've been watching Nepal's covid-19 rates and there are more Nepalese infected outside the country than there is inside, but that could change quickly and Nepal doesn't have the greatest healthcare system. I could see the government adjusting their budget away from the census, but so far, I'm still a yes.

It seems more likely that the population has grown in 5 years. I assume Rhino populations dont have big fluctuations but rather grow slowly until the carrying capacity of the area is reached.  Measurement error flattens the range a bit. Why the count could be higher than last 5 years ago (645): The reported 20 deaths per year is nothing surprising in a population of 645, assuming that the rhinos live 40 years. The birth rate should be around 50 per year if the adult females give birth every 3,5 years (wikipedia). So since the last census we should have 150 more rhinos. The carrying capacity of the park is a question mark but it seems to be above 650 (@Jaystarz) Political incentives are for stating higher number in this census. Why it could be lower: The 2017 flood that apparently drove "dozens" of rhinos elsewhere. The females might have reduced breeding if the carrying capacity is near or if they are old. This would be more interesting data point to know than deaths. Some unreported disease. Giving 10% to the survey not happening because they already failed last year and Nepal doesn't have the best institutions. Also if government realizes that the count will be low, they might not want to reveal it.
There is at least one big heard in there National park

The number of Rhino (Gaidas) in Nepal stood at 612 in 2000.  Nepal has been successful in virtually eliminating poaching of this endangered species which should spell good news for the overall numbers, however the significant number of rhino deaths since July 2018, in and around Chitwan National Park, creates uncertainty as to the actual number that will be counted in the census.

Much focus is given to the population of near extict big mammal species (more then the recovery of ecosystems worldwide, which should be the focus). However: Nepal is lacking a good infrastructure to realize this.

Thanks DiegoG and Jaystarz for their research, insights, and especially the link to "Demography and viability of the largest population of greater one-horned rhinoceros in Nepal." -   https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2351989417300938 - a very informative paper on the science behind Rhino management.   The population growth rate charts along with the governments nationalistic agenda for the gaida will likely result in a population number higher than 650, despite the recently reported losses to natural causes.   Should the survey result in unexpected results (population decline or stagnation) there is a possibility the government would either delay the announcement of results, require a "recount", or make an effort to "spin" results.  This scenario is more about the timing of the results than the results themselves.  Though the government would likely conduct this planning concurrently with the survey and prepare statements based on preliminary updates received as the count continues, the release of the information to the general public may take additional time.  This also does not account for the possibility of a conservation group releasing the results early and forcing the government's hand.  This scenario will require monitoring during the census - looking for indicators of government unease or press releases intended to lower expectations, "irregularities" in census, blaming weather or trafficability, etc.

“There were 645 rhinos in Nepal in 2015. Of them, more than 600 were in Chitwan” (onlinekhabar) “Every two and a half to five years, a female rhino will reproduce. Female rhinos carry their young for a gestation period of 15 to 16 months. They usually only have one baby at a time...” (livescience.com)

The government has budgeted for the 2020 census which is the first time they have done so. They traditionally relied on donations from international organizations, however, due to the greater than average losses of rhinos over the last two years, they have taken decisive action.  Three issues dominate the population size: poaching, natural disasters, and the carrying capacity of the areas where the rhinos live. Poaching has all but been halted by government agencies around Chitwan National Park, which hosted 605 of Nepal's 645 rhinos. Natural disasters relate mostly to monsoon related flooding that drowns the rhinos because their normal habitat runs along rivers. The rivers are where the saccharum spontaneum grass that comprises 80% of their diet is. The grass is being replaced by an invasive woody plant the rhinos can't eat, at a rate of 2%/yr. The other issue is the grass is used by the local population to thatch roofs and as domestic animal fodder. This additional loss has accelerated the invasive species' growth. Both have been identified as an issue, however, little has been done to mitigate the invasive plant's progress to date. In 2016 the carrying capacity of Chitwan NP was estimated to be 800 animals, therefore a reduction of 2% habitat a year would equate to the loss of 8% of habitat, or a carrying capacity of 736 animals by 2019. All growth rate calculations resulted in population numbers above the estimated carrying capacity. Therefore it can be assumed the animal's population growth is now pressing on the upper limit of the park's carrying capacity. This could partially explain the higher than average natural death rate in the last couple of years, in addition to flood losses. There was little data for the animals residing outside of the park, therefore estimates are based on the data related to the park and extended to those animals outside the park. My estimate is a population of 685 to 736 rhinos. https://www.thetrickyscribe.com/chitwan-national-park-the-death-zone-for-rhinos/
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2351989417300938

If the growth rate from the last two census are anything to go by we would be looking at a population of 750+. However, it has been well documented that there has been a spike in rhino fatalities in Nepal, so a continuation of past growth rates seems unlikely.  I suspect we will see a slight increase on the 2015 population (something like 675). My reasons for being confident we won't see a decline are: - A nationalist government is keen to do the survey. This makes me think they are not expecting an embarrassing decline or will artificially boost the figures to satisfy political ends.
- The spike in Rhino fatalities may be down to the Chitwan Park reaching its natural Rhino population limit. Park rangers have not found evidence of widespread disease or anything equally sinister effecting the population.
- The Nepalese government seem to have poaching under control.

A civil war from 1996-2006 makes it difficult to compare figures before 2011.[1] For example, in 2002, poachers killed 37 rhinos.[2] But, we have average rates of deaths for unknown or natural causes for the current period: "Between 2004 and 2014, a total of 81 rhinos died from unknown or natural causes — an average of around seven per year. That number has since shot up: From 2015 to 2017, 60 such deaths were recorded, an average of 20 per year."[3] Let's assume that poaching is low single digits over the period. Census numbers from previous years: 2000: 544
2005: 372
2011: 534
2015: 645 [4,5] Between 2005 to 2015, the annual growth rate was ~27. For 1978 to 2000, the rhino population went from 310 to 612, or an annual growth rate of ~14.[6] Then, we have this statement: "...Ram Chandra Kandel, a deputy director general at the department. says he fears a decline in the total number of rhinos in Nepal. 'Dozens of the rhinos were swept away from Chitwan to India during the 2017 floods. The disaster had a long-term impact on the wildlife,' he says, 'So I am not much hopeful.'...There were 645 rhinos in Nepal in 2015. Of them, more than 600 were in Chitwan."[7] Flooding, a harsher environment, possibly population aging is probably both increasing the death rate and lowering the growth rate closer to the earlier average of ~14. The deputy director is expecting a decline. But, will it be reduced by ~10 per year to get below 601, given what we know of the growth and death rates? It seems unlikely.  An increase seems even less likely, given the flooding in 2017. Putting a bit more of a hedge to below the middle option than above (with both below default) and more or less discounting the top and bottom ends. [7] https://english.onlinekhabar.com/nepal-rhino-census-to-begin-on-march-14-2020.html

There are somewhere around 3,700 rhinos in Nepal, so unless they screw up big-time the chances of them getting less than 550 rhinos is quite low, but getting much more than that is iffy.

“The count, especially in Chitwan, takes around two to three weeks to complete and has to be completed between April and May,” said Naresh Subedi, program manager at the NTNC, one of the funders of the census. “If we miss the window period, the heat becomes unbearable for the elephants and visibility also decreases as grass grows tall.”

The key issues to answer this question are the following: Government of Nepal 1. Will the Nepalese government fund the census?
2. Is the Nepalese government able to pull of the census within one month?
3. Will the government publish the report before 1st July?
4. Will they report accurate numbers? 
5. And if they do not report accurate numbers, what is the number they will likely publish? Rhino population 6. How many rhinos are born each year?
7. How many rhinos have died that we know of since the last census?
8. How many rhinos can we assume to have died based on the information we have on the reasons for fatalities in the past? @Kitsonj and @cerdinga have already discussed most of these questions. It depends to a large degree on the rhinos' fertility (50 babies/year? [1]) and the survival rate of calves and those juveniles that cannot survive on their own (11.1% death rate? [2]). I find this publication on rhinos in Chitwan [3] and its results [4,5] quite interesting ... after taking a quick glance at it.  So all in all, I'm a little bit reluctant regarding the numbers of the rhinos. I'm not particularly sure about the influence poaching has on the population on average [6]. In general, I assume that the Nepal government will pull off the census and its publication in time, mostly due to the buzz the government has made about it [7,8]. This question need to clear up live, and dead animals ?  The animals that are alive so, which are we counting? 
The government announcement comes as significant numbers of Nepal’s rhinos have been dying due to unknown or natural causes. Since mid-July 2018, 45 rhinos have been found dead in and around Chitwan National Park, the country’s main rhino sanctuary.

From 2015-fiscal year 2019 (July in Nepal), 108 rhinos died, mostly from natural causes. This would take the 645 counted in 2015 down to 537, before rhino births and not accounting for unreported deaths + deaths this year. (1) The 2017 floods in the Chitwan national park which swept away 15 rhinos (2) did affect the habitat of the rhinos which remained, which could have contributed to the increase in rhino deaths that year. Another hypothesis is that the increased death rate in the past few years has been due to older rhinos dying of natural causes, (3) as well as more rhinos competing over territory. I have not been able to substantiate the claim that 50 rhinos a year are born (4). I will look to see if this is accurate, but if it is off even by 20% then that would be 200 rhinos born, pushing the figure from 537 to 700+. However, some of the rhinos will migrate, calves may die in childbirth, etc. There are a few things that could otherwise influence the outcome - the census is postponed again, the numbers could be exaggerated for political reasons, the census could be poorly conducted and miss/overestimate. Dropping most in the +650 bracket as if the birth rate is accurate then this will easily push the figure about the 645 recorded in 2015. The previous census had 111 new rhinos from 2011-15, a 21% increase.(5) 1. https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/rhino-census-likely-from-mid-february-till-mid-may/

3. https://news.mongabay.com/2018/10/whats-killing-nepals-rhinos/
4. same as 1

Very rough estimate of change in rhino population since April 2015:
Change in population = A (Surviving births) - B (Deaths)
A. Surviving births estimate:
Rhino population at April 2015 = 645
No. female rhinos estimate -> 320 (50% of total) 
No. female rhinos aged at least 6 years (typical minimum breeding age in wild) estimate = -> 272 (85% of total)
Each breeding-age female rhino tends to produce 1 calf every 3-5 years -> between 272 and 450 births between April 2015 and April 2020: however...
Infant mortality rate for rhinos in wild = 12% -> no. survivors -> between 240 and 396
Assume some % of breeding population does not reproduce, for whatever reason -> reduce no. survivors to somewhere between 190-320 (if 20% non-reproducing) and 215-350 (if 10% non-reproducing)
[https://news.mongabay.com/2019/10/at-indias-assam-zoo-decades-of-experience-lead-to-rhino-breeding-success/]
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/i/indian-rhinoceros/
. Deaths estimate:
Most recent year: minimum of 45 deaths
Previous year: minimum of 30 deaths (assume this holds for the previous years since 2015)
-> 165 minimum over 5 years
Scale up for deaths not detected/reported -> 180 deaths (10% error margin), 200 deaths (20% error margin)
https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/one-rhino-dies-every-eight-days-in-chitwan-national-park/
Overall change: suggests numbers should have held up. Best possible scenario would be an increase of around 170. Worst possible would be a modest decrease. These are very tentative numbers. (Perhaps the overall surviving births number has been brought down by lower reproduction rates or higher calf mortality rates than the historic averages, arising from e.g. pressure on resources, adverse weather conditions etc. However it's hard to see the outcome being much better than the best case scenario as birth rates are subject to biological constraints...)
Next question: if anything less than the best case scenario is the result of the census, would the government allow its publication given they have announced a doubling in population over the last decade? I find this even harder to predict than rhino population rates. Given the scale of the exercise it seems like it would be difficult but not impossible to find a pretext to suppress publication. However, it might be easier simply to publish and to point to a factor like the 2017 floods to explain a disappointing outcome.
